Guest accommodations could be next to resident accommodations but they are friendly folk. Bathrooms are co-ed so I ended up brushing my teeth next to a gentlemen guest; but, toilets and showers have locked doors so no need to worry about privacy. Remember to bring your room key with you to the rest room (it's very large and hard to lose). It's no fun being locked out! The hotel practices energy conservation so the only way to watch the flat screen TV and charge your electronics is with the key (the bell hop will show you how). I'd definitely stay again either for business or leisure.

Reviews.Title: “Great find in an expensive city -”
Reviews.Content: My son and I stayed here on a buisness/leisure trip - he for a job interview and me for a business meeting. We read the reviews before the trip and knew what we were getting. Our bathroom was across the hall and only once did one of us need to wait for the shower; never for the toilet. When we asked staff for another water bottle and to clean the shower floor, both were done IMMEDIATELY. The first floor Cafe Gitane was excellent for breakfast, for tea while reading a book, and for an inexpensive but very good quality dinner. Staff was very friendly. It has an old-time elevator that is staffed and he memorized our floor. They stored our bags on the last day as we toured until late afternoon. A ten-dollar taxi ride form the hotel in Greenwich to midtown and an easy walk across West Side Highway to the wonderful Hudson River Parkway. Keep in mind, we spent our money on good food and a show so four nights in a mini-room was our choosing. It might be difficult in the summer as the power is on your room is on only when the key is inserted, which is while you are there. Nice upper-class touches: shampoo and body wash dispenser in shower; hair dryer at sink; brass trim in the room with hooks to hang things on; large mirror on the non-bed wall; air-conditioner; free bottles of water if you return the bottle; in-room safe in one of the drawers under the bed; slippers, towels and a mini-robe; free WiFi. Take your flip=flops and enjoy the city!

Reviews.Title: “The one place I really looked forward to on my trip to NYC!”
Reviews.Author: HoustonPhotog
Reviews.Content: I traveled to NYC solo and I looked for the most interesting and most memorable hotel I could find. After looking for awhile I came across The Jane which states to have the smallest hotel rooms in all of NYC. I was hooked and very excited because as a photographer I knew this place would make for a great photo op for my friends back home to see. The rooms don't have their own bathroom/shower so don't expect to get that. instead theres a community washroom with individual bathroom and shower stalls. a bit of an inconvenience but something I did not have a problem with at all. After all of the photos I have taken on this trip the one that gets the most comments from my friends and family are the ones of my hotel room here at The Jane! Hilarious. hehe. I paid about $99 a night and thats prolly the cheapest you'll find anywhere in NYC. They even have double occupancy rooms which come with bunk beds so you can get 2 people per room. =) If youre into having a good time, having fun and experiencing new and exciting things then I would definitely suggest The Jane. I had a blast and the photos of myself in the room have remained a conversation piece til this day!

Reviews.Title: “The Jane of Manhattan is a jewel”
Reviews.Author: lovetravel6565
Reviews.Content: The rooms are TINY (5-7ft), designed like ship's cabins with bunk beds or single rooms with a single bed, bathrooms down the hall, coed use, but the location, in the West Village, with cobblestone streets and brownstones, is superb and the price is amazing for Manhattan. Bicycles for guests are complimentary. The subway and bus are about a 10 minute walk, but the Hudson river is only a few steps. You can see the statue of Liberty out the window.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful experience!”
Reviews.Author: shirle1118
Reviews.Content: Just spent 3 nights at the Jane Hotel and enjoyed every minute of it. What a quaint and charming place. I have never been treated so well by every member of the staff that I came in contact with. The room, while tiny, was very clean - NO BED BUG PROBLEMS - and quite adequate for my purposes. It was truly a fun experience and my fellow travelers felt the same.

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel for the price”
Reviews.Author: Johnlcruise
Reviews.Content: Just got back from spending 4 nights at The Jane..Yes the rooms are small. but for as little time I spent in the room it was great..Very clean. Good Beds..(NO bed bugs) Clean Bathrooms and yes they are down the hall. Every time I went to the bathroom nobody was there. GREAT STAFF..Everybody friendly and willing to help you..Be sure to check out the bar. Really nice..A little over price for a drink. But still nice. Great Location. Not to far from the subway. Be sure to go across the street to the bay for a nice walk. Or use one of the bikes the hotel has for you to use. Lots of great resturants in the area. And the area was very safe. If you are traveling solo like myself. this place is worth it..Why pay extra for a room that you will be hardly in. Will stay there again next time in NYC..

Reviews.Title: “BEDBUGSSSSSSSSSSSS”
Reviews.Author: Luvinit91
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Jane On September 20 thru September 27.. I would feel itchy at night and didn't know why then I found tiny blood staing and saw two bedbugs that was upsetting i notified management and I saw the exterminator in there that same day. The gentleman came into the room and sprayed wit while we were given a diffrent room in the meantime I asked them what company they used because I wanted to inquire how were we going to know the bedbugs were gone they used a company based in Staten Island called JB the gentleman looked like he knew what he was doing he answered all the questions i asked him in the hallway his name was Victor ( I belive) he did great I didn't get bitten for the rest of my stay. Great Job to the Jane and JB exterminating and Victor you gusy made me feel great

Reviews.Title: “Great location, cool concept but not the best value for money.”
Reviews.Author: tjtodd
Reviews.Content: First of all I stayed in one of the capt cabins, so quite a large room and en-suite. It was a fairly expensive rate for one night considering the air con was very loud and fairly weak. The ceiling fan did a better job. I gave up on the air con half way through the night. Bed was pretty average. Saying that though, the staff were very friendly, the location is excellent and as a 'concept' type hotel it's a lot of fun. I'd recommend going for a cheap room so you know exactly what you're getting!

Reviews.Title: “Search is over”
Reviews.Author: DCSojourner
Reviews.Content: I travel to NYC multiple times a year have stayed in many different budget hotels and hostels all over the city. This is by far the best value in Manhattan. At around $100/night you get extrememy fresh linens, flat screen TV, and a very comfortable bed. The shared bathrooms are immaculate and they even provide bathrobes. What other budget hotel does that?! I feel like its their attention to the small details is why i like it so much. Also, they have a elevator operator (neat!), a great cafe off the lobby for breakfast or an afternoon pick-me-up, and a great bar. It's basically an awesome hotel at a hostel price. Yes, the rooms are small. But its Manhattan and you only paid $100. Plus, who hangs out in their hotel room in NYC anyway. Its just your luggage that needs a place to stay, and the cleverly placed drawyers and hooks in the room does just the trick. I have plans to return to the Jane twice this fall already. It's my go-to crash pad in Manhattan now, and I need not look further.

Reviews.Title: “Old fashioned European grandeur, a true hipster haven.”
Reviews.Author: Meadoo
Reviews.Content: I stayed in The Jane Hotel with a friend, as we didn't book in advance we stayed in the only rooms which were available, on the first night we shared a double room with a bunk bed, and on the second night we had two single rooms. Over all of stay was fantastic, the place has real character, the rooms are designed to look like sleeper cabins on the old orient express, the one downside of the hotel being that they are sized this was as well. But for a two night stay the limited space is fine. The bathrooms were shared, and even though this worried me a little at first it turned out to be no problem. We never had a problem getting in to use the facilities or take a shower. Now for some info on the shower, it was hands down one of the nicest I have ever used. All the rooms have ipod docks/speakers which was great, I loved being able to put on my music while getting ready to go out. The hotel has a restaurant and bar/club off the lobby, the restaurant which is French inspired and serves food all day, was very good, and I say that as a self proclaimed foodie. They have a good selection of reasonably priced cocktails as well, although the cucumber mint concoction should be avoided unless you are interested in drinking a cucumber. They make an excellent dry gin martini, and the watermelon mimosa was very good. The bar/club on the other side of the lobby, was fantastic. it seems to be a very popular destination at the moment, and they appear to be very controlled about how many people they will allow in, it is a big room decorated with a hodge podge of things, with lots of low velvet chairs and long couches. They seem to only allow as many people as there are places to sit into the bar, which is wonderful allowing for a relaxed intimate environment, the problem is that they have the music volume set just a bit to high, which makes conversation uncomfortable. Four of us met there for drinks after dinner, we had three rounds of very interesting and tasty cocktails (a bit pricey at $15 a pop) and ended up leaving to go to the restaurant for our last round as it would be more comfortable to talk in the there (plus the drinks are more affordable). The location was wonderful, walking distance to everything in the village and to midtown. We walked the couple of blocks to the High Line park as well, an experience not to be missed. Over all I would highly recommend The Jane Hotel to my friends, I don't think I would send my parents there but for well traveled and continental twenty somethings with a little extra money to spend it is a great weekend getaway.

Reviews.Title: “Great location at a great price”
Reviews.Author: jcarjr
Reviews.Content: We stayed in a Captain's Cabin - the room was excellent and we had a river view which was lovely. The Jane is in a great location - lots of bars and restaurants within easy walking distance and really close to the subway for going uptown or over to Brooklyn. We would definitely recommend the Jane to other people, it's a fun, quirky place to stay at a great price in a great location.

Reviews.Title: “BEWARE OF BED BUGS!!!!”
Reviews.Author: livinludlow
Reviews.Content: My husband and I recently stayed at The Jane hotel for one night as we traveled to Boston via NYC. The night we spent there was average, the rooms are tiny, but seemed clean, the building is amazing. Hind site is 20/20. As we were packing up to leave I had noticed several tiny blood spots on my sheets, didn't really give it much thought assuming I had cut my arm before heading to bed. Now I know that this is a tale tell sign of a bed bug infestation and the reason I know is because we carried these awful creatures home with us from the hotel. As I did more research I found that The Jane has had issues for over a year and is on the Bed Bug Registry with several complaints one dating within days of when my husband and I were there. I was totally grossed out and completely appalled that it appears the staff and management is completely aware of the problem but continues to remain open without notifying guests of the risk. I have contacted management and they will not get back to me. Such a pitty the hotel is affordable and the location is amazing.

Reviews.Title: “Super Fun!”
Reviews.Author: Mickinak
Reviews.Content: Yes the rooms are small - The Jane doesn't lie about that on its website, etc... - I didn't travel to NYC to sit in my hotel room - but if I had - I could watch a flat screen tv with CABLE, get room service from the Cafe within the hotel, relax and take a nap... open the window and access fresh air... or walk down to the hotel lobby to have a drink in the beautiful hotel bar..... the bathroom was immaculate - and the shower - if I could have dismantled the shower head I would have. The staff was friendly, polite and provided me with the non-smoking room I requested and held my luggage so I could spend my final day in NYC shopping and museum-hopping This hotel is in a great neighborhood with access to everything from expensive restaurants to hot dog vendors, walking paths on the Highline and West Side Highway... I hope to return very very soon!!!!!

Reviews.Title: “Great SHOWER / Noisy A/C”
Reviews.Author: OXMINSTER
Reviews.Content: A bitter-sweet experience. This commentary refers to the single or double cabins. CON: -The noise of the A/C unit, whether it's on High or Low, makes the same obnoxious dinning noise. Wearing earplugs, it faintly sounds like you are on a night flight. PROS: -If it's anything that would bring you back for the affordable rate and the amenities that match it, is the Rain Shower, ....beautiful! -The loos are clean and quite presentable. -The two sinks on the marble counter in the bathroom area are nice and clean. -Cafe on the premises. -The Cocktail lounge hall is DECADENT! (and the grotto-esque bar area). -Staff are pleasant. -Nice flat screen TVs with cable in each room, ... and TWO TVs in the double-bunk rooms. HEADS-UP! -If you're a man (lucky us), ...have an empty bottle on hand in your room before tucking in to bed, .....it comes in handy, not needing to leave your room to go down the hallway to the loo in the wee hours of the night. (Let's not kid ourselves, we will all do it for the convenience!). -There are people who RESIDE in The Jane (who would appear 'not' to belong there), ...yes, 'their' living arrangements are exactly the same as the hole-in-the-wall room you're staying in! -There are two drawers under the bed. -There are NO CLOSETS or COAT HANGERS!, ...just hooks on the back of the door and along the mirrored wall. -Don't expect to roll luggage in to room and spread out, ..noooooo space!

Reviews.Title: “Short and sweet-very compact and cozy”
Reviews.Author: SWDCRED
Reviews.Content: If you are looking for just a room in NYC without spending $ then go to the Jane. It is a little off the beaten path in regards to the subway (which is good for some) but it serves a purpose-small rooms that don't cost a fortune. If you get a room with the bunkbeds it is very small. The shared bathrooms were spotless and the bar and lounge were very cozy. In addition the French-styled cafe was light and airy. I would go back but make sure you get the bottom bunk.

Reviews.Title: “A stay out of the ordinary.”
Reviews.Author: thatagirl2
Reviews.Content: I stayed in the large captain;s room and it was spacious and lovely. The bed was very comfortable and I slept very well. The French restaurant attached to the lobby has amazing food and seems to be a destination spot for the locals. So, after a great night sleep and a perfect cappuccino with a square of chocolate I crumbled on top (again, at the restaurant), I rented one of Jane's bikes (10 dollars) and road the streets of Greenwich Village and up and down the park path along the Hudson. Finally, the staff was authentically friendly and helpful and seemed to enjoy working at The Jane.

Reviews.Title: “Best in Class”
Reviews.Author: NYCHoya
Reviews.Content: When compared to any other hotel in Manhattan that is in the less than $100p night category, there is no question in my mind that the Jane hotel is the best. I must admit that I was quite frightened to stay at the Jane after reading some of the reviews. However, I can confirm that I was pleasantly surprised with my stay. Yes, the rooms are microscopic, even for NYC. Nonetheless, they are clean, safe and it really has all that you need. I was skeptical of the shared bathrooms but I also found that these were kept super clean and they were actually pretty nice. My only complaint with The Jane is that I didn't sleep very well. Perhaps, I could blame this on the lights in the room or the sometimes noisy hallways at random hours of the night, or maybe it is because I am a light sleeper. For me, the Jane gets major points for being in the the ABSOLUTE best part of Manhattan. There are so many amazing restaurants and bars nearby, it's adjacent to the Hudson River Park which is great for running. It's also pretty close to ACE and L train which can take you pretty much everywhere. Lastly, the Ballroom at The Jane is one of the best places to go out in the city, granted you probably won't get in unless you are with Mary-Kate Olson. In summary, as a 25 year student, I would totally stay here again for a night or two. Ask me again in a couple of years and I hope to have upgraded to The Standard by then. Just remember that you get what you pay for (so don't expect the Waldorf) but in my opinion and as a former New Yorker, you get a decent amount (in NYC dollars) for your money. PS. To avoid the so-called homeless smelling floors or smokey floors, just request a non-smoking floor.

Reviews.Title: “Tiny room, huge value!”
Reviews.Author: nickvalentino
Reviews.Content: Well, let's the elephant out of the room first - the rooms are small! But you already knew that! Now the upside, the location is amazing, the staff is very welcoming, and the French cafe off the lobby has charm off the scale. It's located in a quiet and peaceful part of NYC, just a block or two from the action of uber trendy Meat Packing District! With the money you save at The Jane, you can actually afford the restaurants and clubs in MPD and the West Village! If you're a little worried about the shared bathroom, don't be. Both the showers and toilets are completely enclosed individual "rooms" for total privacy. In my experience, the marble sinks have always been clean and well maintained. And rarely do you even encounter another person in the bathroom anyway! The only downside is if you're taking the subway to The Jane, it's a pretty good walk from the nearest stop which is 14th St. and 8 Ave. If you have luggage and you're arriving from JFK on the E train for example, I'd suggest getting a cab for a $5 ride from the stop to the hotel. I've walked it a few times with wheeled luggage and it's a good 10 min walk. Other than that, don't hesitate to try this hotel - it's both historic and charming - and you absolutely can't beat the value in Manhattan. Also, WiFi access is fast and free.

Reviews.Title: “Disgusting”
Reviews.Author: NYCGinger
Reviews.Content: At first I thought my room (#340) smelled like a wet dog. After a long trip, I was willing to put up with it for a one-night stay. When I lay down, I realized it wasn't a wet-dog smell, it was a homeless person smell. It is now 2 a.m., and the stench has grown unbearable. I'd like to check out immediately, but the earliest train to my destination on Long Island doesn't leave until 7:30 a.m. I had been planning on a leisurely morning in the city and the noon train. Now it looks like I will be going first thing in the morning on three hours sleep. I booked this after reading about the place in a news story online about cute, cheap hotels in the city. Don't risk it. It's sooooo gross.

Reviews.Title: “The Jane...what a shame!”
Reviews.Author: seewick
Reviews.Content: I wanted to love the Jane. Great location. So tastily decorated. Cool. People that work there nice. Not too expensive by New York standards. I could even tolerate the tiny rooms because they are so beautifully done but...the airconditioner in my room was so loud and sounded like a 747. It was hot in the city but even hotter in the hotel. The hallways were smelly and humid. When I arrived in my room it was dreadfully hot. You have to insert your key into the wall to turn on the aircon. It took well over an hour for it to be inhabitable. What they don't tell you is there are tenants living in the hotel building so even if you can stand the noise of your aircon in your tiny room...you may not be able to stand the smell of cigarette smoke which wafts into the room from it. The hotel is located on the West side highway so it is very noisy with traffic sounds all night long. Also not near a subway stop. So The Jane...what a shame.

Reviews.Title: “Long on details, short on space--and an acquired taste.”
Reviews.Author: TravelBeard
Reviews.Content: Whatever your thoughts on The Jane Hotel, you are bound to remember it. And actually, there is much to recommend the hotel. But still, it may not be for youâ€”given tiny rooms and shared baths. The location is central, convenient, and wonderful on many levelsâ€”Jane Street near the Hudson Riverâ€”as it puts guests in the heart of the West Village, and near the parks that line the river. The now-trendy Meatpacking District is just a few blocks away, the south entrance of the High Line park is close at hand, and the tree-lined residential streets in this part of the Village surround the hotel. The streets appear to be as safe as any in NYC--expensive cars are parked outside, and people stroll at all hours. We were in town for NYC Pride, and Christopher Street is about 10 minutes away. The closest subway station is 8 blocksâ€™ walkâ€”at 14th Street and 8th Avenue--at the south gateway to Chelsea. The 1907 building that once housed The Seamanâ€™s Home and a YMCA is a handsome brick structure, and the first floor has considerable architectural charm. . .tapestries, tilework, and interesting lighting. CafÃ© Gitane is right off the main lobby. The staff wears period hotel costumes, from pillbox hats to French maid uniforms. The Jane ballroom is right off this space--many evenings with a bar scene or private party--an impressive room. To get you to your room, there is a cage elevator and a staircase nearbyâ€”given the waits, you may find yourself using the stairs more than youâ€™d like. As well, the elevator was out a few times during our five night stay. The hotel rooms are likely the smallest you have ever seen--about a third of the average cruise ship cabin. The two of us stayed in a double bunked room, about 45 square feet (about 8x6) â€”just big enough for the two twin bunk beds and room to get into them. No closet, just a rod for hooks, and a mirror the length of the room. There are two drawers under the lower bunk, and a cubby on the top and bottom of the same bunk for storage. Two flat screen TVsâ€”one for each bunk. The detail of the room is very niceâ€”tin ceilings, nice wallpaper and paint, and good materials. And wifi is free. All the same, you will have to leave the room to change your mind. And we never had our bunks made--not once during our five night stay. In the name of energy efficiency, the key device needs to be inserted into the electricity panel in order to get A/C to work, or to get the lights to work. As a result, the room can take awhile to cool. If the A/C is working for a bit, the room will cool. The bathrooms are down the hall--you are furnished towels and skimpy bathrobes/slippers in your room. The shared bathrooms are, oddly, co-ed (would have preferred a single sex configuration instead) with two shower stalls, and two water closetsâ€”all with lockable doors. Again, the detail is nice, with black & white tile and marble vanity tops. And the showers have rain shower headsâ€”so the shower is sublime. Shampoo, soap and conditioner are dispensed in the shower stall. While the hotel appears to make an effort to keep the bathrooms clean, sheer volume prevents that at timesâ€”and the shower/water closet experience is less favorableâ€”considerably soâ€”when things arenâ€™t clean. By and large, the staff is pleasantâ€”at times, very much soâ€”though at times, an occasional hipster misplaced in a service role ruins the vibe. CafÃ© Gitane, the restaurant in the hotel, looks better than it tastes. Was very disappointed in the breakfast offerings for a restaurant attached to a hotelâ€”no brewed coffee in the morning, for example, and a very limited set of breakfast foodâ€”and the tables are close enough to use the salt and pepper shakers of the people sitting next to you. A beautiful room, though--one that likely photographs well. In all, I think The Jane is an acquired taste. It can be perfect for those seeking a great Village location at a low price. If so, you have to determine if you can put up with one of the worldâ€™s smallest hotel rooms, and the unique joys of shared baths. If the West Village location is not as important to you, you could likely find a much better NYC hotel room on Priceline at a comparable price in midtown.

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel with character”
Reviews.Author: jaiessa
Reviews.Content: Where to start? The Jane is a great little hotel. The rooms are tiny, its like a train or ship cabin â€“ so be warned but you are in NYC so you shouldnâ€™t be spending too much time in them anyway. The room is equipped with A/C & a fan, TV, IPOD dock/alarm clock and safe. The mattress was a little on the thin side as its just a piece of foam but I managed to sleep well during my stay. The shared bathrooms were very clean and there was rarely a wait to use ether a shower or toilet â€“ although it was a little weird to learn that theyâ€™re shared by both male & female guests â€“ although you get used to this pretty quickly. They also provide Shampoo, Conditioner & Body wash in the showers. The location of the hotel was perfect â€“ very close to The High Line & Chelsea market with some great restaurants, bars and shops within walking distance. A few other reviews have mentioned issues with Taxiâ€™s â€“ I didnâ€™t have to wait for one at all during my 10 night stay â€“ a taxi into & around time sq was roughly $10 which I thought was pretty decent. The staff were great, although a couple of them had a little attitude. The one major issue that I did have was the elevator â€“ it hardly worked. After a day of walking around it was a little disappointing that the elevator wasnâ€™t working as I was on the 5th floor! Overall I had a great stay at the Jane and would recommend it to my friends and family if they are even in NYC.

Reviews.Title: “VERY small but clean & great location”
Reviews.Author: SteveStefan
Reviews.Content: The hotel is in a great location. The rooms are VERY small, so if you are not good in small spaces, forget it! The room is he size of a double bed - no kidding. Its clean and the shared bathrooms are clean and pretty good. The bunk bed rooms make the rooms feel very small. If you on a tight budget, and have very little luggage, this is the place to stay. NB: The air conditioners are a little noisy, and theer are still some of the original residence living in the hotel who smoke and are a little out of he ordinary.

Reviews.Title: “nice hotel........”
Reviews.Author: unitedAmman
Reviews.Content: Nice hotel with helpful staff â€¦â€¦.room is small, but it is not small for Manhattanâ€¦acceptable shared bathrooms, I recommend this hotel for any one want to enjoy Manhattan without spending a lot of money .

Reviews.Title: “priceless”
Reviews.Author: jh129
Reviews.Content: price of 3 nights: $351, price of dinner at the cafe with a drink: $26, meeting a nice Swedish girl in the cafe and not getting a name or number priceless. All joking aside the rooms are small but if you are going to NYC your probably not going to stay in the hotel 24/7. Staff was excellent and enjoyed the food in the cafe, had people cleaning daily so it stayed nice. There is street parking but not a whole lot, there is however a garage just up the street at about $45 for 24hrs if you chose to drive. found it to be a decent location furthest thing i went to was central park and that is only 3.7 miles walking distance. there also happen to be a lot of restaurants in the area.

Reviews.Title: “Major Dump with Alacrity!”
Reviews.Author: TravellingSport
Reviews.Content: For the rate of $117 per weekend nite, it was way overpriced! The room was the size of a storage closet with a bed that was smaller than a twin bed. Moreover, the bed was not comfortable at it: the mattress about 4 inches high and is filled with foam and is placed on top of a wooden frame. Moreover, the staff is very unfriendly. Furthermore, when I asked for a late check out of only 30 minutes more, they said that it wasn't possible and I had to check out at 12 noon on a monday. When I did check out at 12 noon, I saw at least 20 rooms that were available at the front desk (the room keys are stored in room boxes behind the check-in desk), so it wasn't as if the hotel needed my room immediately! You are better off staying at a hotel outside of Manhattan that is right by a subway station. The location of the Jane hotel was so remote from public transportation and taxis were far and few to hail to get to the "heart" of the city. So, the time spent travelling from a nice and spacious hotel for the same cost would be the same to travel to any of the NYC destinations from the Jane hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Small but perfectly formed!”
Reviews.Author: KateSMJ
Reviews.Content: The Jane is in a great part of town - Jane St itself is quiet and tree lined, with cobbles as it si in the old part of Greenwich Village. But, only 3 blocks away and you are in the Meatpacking district proper with bars and restaurants everywhere. Given the price of this hotel the location is excellent. The Subway is also just 3 blocks away on 8th Av and felt very safe, even at night. OK - the cabins are small, but isn't that obvious from the name? The single has about the same space again as the bed and the bunk rooms have slightly less - add in two peoples baggage and it's a tight squeeze! But the shared bathrooms are immaculate and the staff are extremely helpful. You get all the perks you expect from a hotel (tv, dvd, room service, bathrobe, towels, toiletries) just with less space. For me, the point of going to New York was not to hang out in a hotel room so it fit the bill perfectly and left me with enough spare money to really enjoy the city.

Reviews.Title: “Cheap and clean enough.”
Reviews.Author: keyok
Reviews.Content: The Jane is a young hotel, and has some rough edges, which is particularly noticeable in the services provided. While some staff were very friendly and went above the call of duty (JP, Carlos, Jose), others were less so. e.g. when I wanted some boiled water front desk just said "sorry, we don't have the equipment for it", yet there is a bar AND a cafe on the ground floor. The room was clean and didn't smell bad or was particularly noisy, though I was on the 4th floor. The shared bathroom wasn't too bad, though the supplied slippers were worthless, and the showers have offer no facility to keep your towel or bathrobe dry. Take a few plastic bags with you. They do however offer free shampoo, conditioner, and body wash. The residents/visitors were all very friendly - didn't run into any stranger or creepy characters. YMMV. The cafe is fantastic, especially since they had some proper black tea. They are open 7am to midnight, and is a great choice for snacks or a meal. Free WIFI is available, and it is really free WIFI: you don't even need a password. You could be a random walking into the hotel and get it. I liked this. I hate the song and dance other places make you do just to check your email. This is also full internet access, not some restricted http/s proxy business. Overall I liked the Jane, and the good out weight the bad. A bit more polish on the staff, and a little more service would make this an excellent hotel for those wanting to see NYC on a budget.

Reviews.Title: “you need a chiropractor after your stay in the hotel”
Reviews.Author: HamilToner
Reviews.Content: Well, where do I begin with the review... Im trying to convince myself that I got a very good deal because I only paid $550 for 4 days and 3 nights, including airfare from my country of origin which is like 2 hours flight, and also it includes the shuttle bus (pick up and drop off from airport to the hotel) . Location is great... I get to walk along Hudson river, maybe 2 blocks away from the hotel. I love walking so I get to walk around Soho, and West Village (lots of great restaurant here). Elevator doesnt work at all, on my 4th day in the hotel, the bellboy told me that elevator is now working *sighs.. thanks goodness, i was staying on the 5th floor. The room is extremely small.. its like a room in a Train. theres an aÃ­rcondition, tv, and safety box vault.. although, i never experience anything that is stolen from my stuff... bathroom is shared... dont get me wrong, bathroom is very clean, they have shower room and toilet room in the bathroom that you can lock... but you will be surprised that youre brushing your teeth and somebody will take a poop and you can hear them moaning while taking a poop.. soo disgusting... you can even smell their s__HIT while youre in the middle of flossing your teeth.. i will always hurry back to my room whenever that happens... Staff are very friendly.. that black guy that works at night, he is very nice, i called him at 2am, because I was extremely thirsty, i was asking for any available vending machine in the building and the cafeteria is already closed.. he said, if I have empty bottle, he will be gladly to fill up the water for me... :) so I went downstairs, and he fill up the bottle from their office... thats really nice of him... The bed is extremely uncomfortable, im tall, so imagine how I tried so hard to make myself comfortable sleeping, and it is very very narrow... try sleeping in your 3 seater sofa (not the leather sofa okay..thats how it feels) and when you get up in the morning, your back will hurt sooo bad... I really need to go to a chiropractor after the trip from NY... You can also hear the noises when people that are passing by or when youre outside the hallway, you can hear the sound of their television, you can also smell the clorox from the laundry when youre staying in your room... oh, please bring flipflops, they have this crappy paper (or plastic) flipflops, which is only good for 20 minutes, and then it breaks... so, whenever you have to go to the bathroom, you can use your flipflops .. they will provide you with a small towel, and this bath robe (which is like a jacket of my grandma.. coz its very short.. where did you see a bath robe which is above your waistline.... i think its a jacket *lol) If youre under budget.. Im gonna say, Yes.. this is a good hotel.. great location (unless youre lazy to walk like some of the reviewers here, Cmmon people.. Soho is like 20 minutes walk from The Jane Hotel), very quiet neighborhood... I was even thinking, if i move to NYC, im gonna move to this neighborhood... but dont expect to have a great sleep.... oh, and theres a lot of gay guys that checkin to the hotel, because apparently.. the hotel is very close to West Village and Chelsea... But when it comes to comfortability, nah.. forget it... its not gonna happen if you stay in this hotel.. If youre around the area.. check out the farmers market... its really great...

Reviews.Title: “Val Kilmer Rocks!”
Reviews.Author: GonzoNose
Reviews.Content: The girl with the glasses is super awesome. She had yellow painted finger nails! She protected our heavy brass key every night and made sure to give it back to us so we could enter our room. The guy working with her was also really cool. He went out of his way to call up the Ace Hotel for accommodations over the weekend since the Jane was booked. If we could have stayed longer we would have. I think the bunk beds made the trip. Awesome. My hair still smells like peppermint from the shampoo. There were was an old man with ashy skin walking back and forth in the halls in his bath towel at night and that made the hotel experience "authentic" for me. The Jane is hip, fun, and we will definitely be back. For a hostel the bathrooms were immaculate; the doors of the bathroom are designed to seal in all the funk and give you privacy. Cool elevators.

Reviews.Title: “An all-around let-down”
Reviews.Author: sallassmiley
Reviews.Content: Where do I begin? OK, location is very inconvenient. The west village is so beatutiful, true, but the hotel is all the way over at the west side hwy. If the weather is not beautiful, you're going to spend a fortune on taxis, which are scarce. If you have great weather, its at least a 20-30 minute walk to Soho, the Village, etc. So, you really don't have a good "base" during your trip. Next, the staff - generally ok, but not at all polished. I hate those weird monkey suits they all wear. The rooms (I had a deluxe with privte bathrm) are small, which is ok, but lets just say weirdly furnished with tiny little $100 window AC units that are noisy. The bathroom amentities are not graciously replenished or replenished at all for that matter. The cafe staff is nice and energetic. Ok, now for the worst part: The bar/lounge. Gret looking with a cool vibe, but- get this - Its strictly off-limits to hotel guests every night after 9 pm. What's that all about? that really put a damper on my stay. then, when I was allowed in (before 9) I had a drink and wasn't allowed to charge it to my room!! Then, the cocktail waitress insisted she follow me to get my credit card so I wouldn't "bolt" on her. I recommend avoiding this place. Its a glorified youth hostel in an out of the way location. It tries hard to create a vibe, but It just misses.

Reviews.Title: “Good value, but bad additude”
Reviews.Author: nikta80
Reviews.Content: It is tiny, but no rats. Good value, but expect a snooty attitude from the staff. Just got hassled by the doorman as I entered the place, and was refused service earlier for something that was supposed to be included, for no good reason. Weird. Almost thinks its cooler than it is. Can't open window for smell of pee.

Reviews.Title: “A Nifty Place”
Reviews.Author: Jim33852
Reviews.Content: Easy to find, near West Side Highway, yet seemed like a quiet corner. Found Street Parking in the neighborhood! The beautifully finished room didn't seem sooo small once I got into it-in fact, it seemed more cozy & comfortable than a motel room. Nice flat-screen TV worked well. Wood paneling & trim, marble shelves, everything in good condition & clean. I felt right at home with the "vintage" ambiance of the whole property. The "shared bath" was perfectly clean, not too far from the room, and had good water pressure for the fifth floor in NYC! Easy walk to 14th St. Subway station. There's even a good diner on Washington street, right near The Standard Hotel, which I forgot the name of (Chico's?) Absolutely plan on making this my "home base" in New York!

Reviews.Title: “Lovely place in every little detail”
Reviews.Author: Emchen
Reviews.Content: My small cabin was my haven when I got stuck in New York because of the Icelandic volcano. I stayed in one of the single cabins; small but cosy and perfectly decorated. Many hooks to hang your clothes and practical space underneath the bed to accomodate your luggage. Every little detail was carefully thought through and I love that attention to detail in designing a hotel. I found the common bathrooms just as nice, with black and white tiled private shower cabins. The bed was comfortable but narrow; since its only for one person. The only negative aspect of my stay was that the window didnt block much of the traffic noises, so my sleep was a bit interrupted at times. But hey, its New York city right!? And they have rooms facing the other direction...

Reviews.Title: “Not upscale but so what - a cool place”
Reviews.Author: RonChgo
Reviews.Content: I wasn't surprised by the small rooms. The Jane doesn't pretend to be something it's not. I've stayed in other shared bathroom places, and this was by far the best. I wasn't all that happy that the shared bath is co-ed, but it was clean, and the showers were quite fine. There were a few seedy looking characters around the hallways, but not a deal. The staff was over the top friendly - from check in, to the bellboys, the woman cleaning the bathroom on Sunday, and the elevator operators. The restaurant was crowded but fun on Sunday morning. Don't plan on a 5 star you'll get pampered place. It's on the cheap, but a good place to sleep.

Reviews.Title: “not for claustrophobics, it's basically a glorified SRO”
Reviews.Author: lalala5458
Reviews.Content: â€Ž I don't think I would ever stay here again. Yes, the price is right, but the bunk bed rooms are smaller than what I'd imagine a jail cell to be, the cigarette smoke from other guests could be smelled in our "room," and our neighbor was a creepy full-time resident who stayed up past 3 am watching tv. Also, sharing a bathroom, especially w/ full-timers, is kind of anxiety-inducing. This place is too pretentious, too, and full of wannabe hipsters, which is too bad, because the cafe is lovely, and makes you feel like you are traveling elsewhere in the world, very far away. They need to knock some walls down and add some bathrooms to start to live up to their cachet. Also, I felt itchy in the bed. I'm just sayin'.

Reviews.Title: “Not a hotel. This is a rooming house/ youth hostel.”
Reviews.Author: warren393
Reviews.Content: I was staying in NYC for only one night and wanted to avoid paying $300+ for a hotel room downtown. Well, you get what you pay for. The website made the Jane look like a chic boutique hotel with fancy amenities and small rooms. What they don't tell you is that there are many residents still living there from the building's days as an SRO (rooming house for the poor). I had no idea to expect this, as the website neglected to mention this. Needless to say, there were many unsavory people roaming the halls, and when i arrived back at the hotel at 12:30am the front desk was empty. This made me feel quite unsafe. The "communal" bathroom is also CO-ED, so when you step out of the shower in a very small bathrobe, you don't know who might be standing there. and the shower was out of soap. i upgraded to one of the captain's cabin's after my first communal shower experience but was still shaken up by the whole experience. The hallways are musty and wreak of smoke. Staying here was a huge mistake.

Reviews.Title: “want to feel like you just walked into a wes anderson film?”
Reviews.Author: thatgirlinlondon
Reviews.Content: This hotel is oh so lovely. I am an 19 year old ex New Yorker and was just looking for a place to stay in the Village without crashing a friends studio and the Jane did just the trick! Yes, the rooms are the size of my walk-in closet, yes, the bathrooms are shared, but it's okay, because eveything is clean, private--and the showers are fantastic. In a place this charming, the size becomes unimportant, especially because they've provided plenty of clever storage. The staff is friendly and extremely helpful, Cafe Gitane in the lobby is fantastic and the PM noise level wasn't as bad as I was expecting. Most of the other visitors seemed to be rather young and also very familiar with the city. Stay here with minimal expectations and you will be very pleased, I promise!

Reviews.Title: “Try it - you might be the "Jane"-type”
Reviews.Author: molevin
Reviews.Content: Yes, the location is a bit off track (basically at the West Side Hwy), the building is old, for most rooms you have to share a bathroom , the climate control is very eccentric, and to say the rooms are tiny is a serious overstatement (mine was literally 6x8 feet - I am not kidding). However - the room and bed seemed clean enough, as were the bathrooms (which are indeed coed although the showers and toilets are individual and lock-able), there were lots of (friendly by NYC standards) staff around dressed in 1940's style uniforms, the price is unbelievable (I paid $69+tax), and the place is kind of fun. The rooms are called cabins and look like a ship's cabin with lots of wood, drawers under the bed, and hooks along the wall. (the place was originally built 100 years ago for beached sailors). The restaurant on the first floor, Le Gitane is outstanding. When I arrived very late Sat night it was open and serving dinner - I got a Stella and a bowl of spiced Moroccan olives and oranges which was tres bien and breakfast the next morning - orange brioche and perfect very strong coffee - was just as good. And, btw there is free wifi in your room, a service almost every other hotel delights in charging for even though it basically costs them nothing. So - if you need an in-room bathroom, a fluffy mattress, reliable climate control, and are even a little bit claustrophobic, DO NOT stay here unless you are masochistic. But - if you feel like a bit of an adventure, and have something else to buy with the $200 or more you will save each night, try it. I will definitely be back.

Reviews.Title: “great business experience at jane hotel”
Reviews.Author: kylebgorman
Reviews.Content: I was in New York for a conference and just needed a place to rest my head, so the small rooms at the Jane were a good match for me. Also the staff was very helpful...the girl at the counter helped me for a long time when I left my mobile in a taxi. The couscous and the avocado toast at Cafe Gitane (connected) was also fabulous.

Reviews.Title: “Everything you need at half the NY price”
Reviews.Author: tokyomike55
Reviews.Content: The Jane has two major room types -- those where you have to share a bathroom with other guests, and the larger more expensive rooms where you have it all to yourself. I was in the larger private room which, after taxes, was about $200 a night, which is not bad for New York -- a city that is pretty much insanely overpriced for most everything involving tourism and entertainment. The staff at the Jane are amazingly friendly -- which I later found to be a trait of everybody in New York. The front desk and bell staff were warm, smiling and helpful. The rooms were also great. Spacious and with this amazing walk-in shower. The feeling is a bit old New York -- it's not bright and glitzy, but very subdued. I loved the decor. Very comfortable bed and an in-room safe that was big enough to even get my laptop in. The free wifi was fast -- although it was down for the first 2 nights due to a technical problem. There's a big flat-screen TV in the rooms, and all kinds of adjustable lighting. I can't comment on the maid service as I didn't use it (trying to be an eco warrior.lol) but my colleague had his room cleaned and said it was OK. If you need it, you need to put a sign outside your door to request it specifically. Finally, the hotel is away from the main streets so it's ultra quiet. I travel with ear plugs, but didn't need to use them. Note that the Jane was renovated not so long ago (not sure when) -- and according to the guys at the front desk, it used to be pretty bad there. So I'd stick to more recent reviews of the Jane when you're trying to decide if it's right for you. And some small points -- the windows in the room open from the top -- you kind of pull it from the top and it pivots on the bottom. I almost took one off the hinge at first trying to open it till I figured it out. Also, they don't make change, so be sure to have a few small bills to tip the bell staff when you get there. To their credit, when we arrived, both my biz partner and I had no small bills -- we apologized and the guys carrying our bags just smiled and of course said it was no problem. We tipped them later in the evening, but it was nice to have that genuine nice attitude from them. Whoever hires for the Jane is doing a great job of it! Although we were working in the day, we explored the city a bit by night, and I took one morning by myself just for sightseeing. It was my first trip to New York, and I was lucky enough to have 18 degree Celsius sunny weather in March. If you're also a first timer, here's some things I did that I'd recommend to anyone staying in NY. 1. Walk a lot. It's a very vertical city, so be sure to look up. The architecture is amazing. We walked from the Jane, which is by the Hudson river near W14th and 9th, all the way up to Madison Square Garden one night, then the next night from the start of Central Park, all through the park, then back through the city from about 82nd, all the way down through Times Square till about 44th. I've never been so happy to get stopped by red lights crossing the street -- more time to just look around and appreciate how utterly cool the city is. 2. The Jane is near (in?) the Meatpacking District, which has an incredible amount of very cool outdoor restaurants and bars. And yes, cool = expensive. But it's a great area to be located. 3. In my morning sightseeing trip, I took a cab down to Battery Park, which is at the southern tip of Manhattan, looking out toward the Statue of Liberty. Everybody told me not to actually go to the Statue as the line ups are endless. So I just took a picture from the park, then headed up for a walk by Trinity Church and into Wall Street. Then I took the subway up to 14th. I'm used to the Tokyo subway system, which is ultra modern -- so the New York one was a bit of an eye opener. It was like something out of the 1940s. But a must-do if you're there. 4. Philly Cheese-steak sandwich. MMmmmmm! Try one, for sure! I had one at the diner near Madison Square Gardens on the corner of W34th and 8th. OK, it's not "New York food," but it was amazing nonetheless. And if you like having a good burger and shake in the park, then hit the "Shake Shack" in Madison Square park -- just go to W23rd and 5th Avenue and look for the line up in the park. We waited 45 minutes as it was lunch and the weather was gorgeous. Not the very best burger you'll have, but worth the wait if it's a sunny day in the park. I think that visiting New York at least once in your life is something everybody should do, and the Jane is an amazingly clean, comfortable and well located base to do it. I'd recommend it to anybody.

Reviews.Title: “Great stay”
Reviews.Author: sampa01425
Reviews.Content: My wife and I - mid 30's - stayed in a bunk bed room at the Jane while we had a two day layover in NY. After booking I read some of the reviews on this site and I told my wife, "lower your expectations; maybe it's not as good as it seems on the web site." However, I can report that our stay was great, we really liked the Jane. It was clean, even the shared bathrooms. My wife is a clean freak, and even she said it was very clean. Yes, the room is SUPER small, but for that price what do you expect? The room is a place to sleep, not lounge around in all day on a honeymoon! We didn't find any "bedbugs" at all, like a previous reviewer said. The staff was quite friendly and helpful in every way. We have zero complaints from our stay. In fact, it will be my hotel of choice when passing through NY again. The location is perfect. (I did hear they are raising their rates from someone at front desk, but not sure when that goes into effect) The elevator was broken during our stay, but it was only a minor thing. The bell boys were more than willing to help up haul our heavy bags up the satirs.

Reviews.Title: “Lots of character, great stay, friendly staff.”
Reviews.Author: evilpollux
Reviews.Content: I stayed in room 516 from March 12th until the 14th 2010. Single female 27 traveler. It was a very cool hotel! Lots of character and history in the building. Cafe Gitane was super handy for snacks and breakfasts. The staff were excellent. From the front desk, to elevator operator to cafe staff they were all extremely helpful and very nice. Housekeeping changes the sheets, they supply you with two towels, a bottle of water, two glasses, a bathrobe and flip-flops. I thought that was a nice touch. The room was super tiny, but for what I paid, I didn't really expect it to be big. Shared bathrooms but they were very clean but were never busy. Location was AMAZING. I loved staying in Chelsea/West Village. It was a quick walk to get cabs, cool restaurants, cafes, shops, and nightlife. The only cons were that they had a very active boiler and that made the room a little warm, but nothing a open window couldn't solve. The Jane is also a SRO, so there were some sketchy people living there. But after striking up a conversation with some them, they turned out not to be so sketchy and they had really interesting stories! They looks rougher than they are. Bedbugs - I heard reports that the hotel might have them. When I first got to my room a tore the bed apart looking for any evidence that might be there. Nothing. I hung all my bags and clothes up just to be sure and covered my backpack in a plastic bag. I did not see any bedbugs during my stay, I wasn't bitten by anything, and I even went through all my clothes when I got home just to be sure. Nothing, notta, zip. Doors are thin so you can hear a few people coming and going, but it didn't bother me. All in all I had a great stay. I would stay there again if I was on a tight budget, wanted a 'character' hotel and wanted to be in an awesome neighbourhood.

Reviews.Title: “simple crash pad with stable rates”
Reviews.Author: sshannon
Reviews.Content: I am an ex-long time NYer who stays overnight 10-12 times a year while doing things I used to do when I lived there. I have become a big fan of the Jane because of its consistency and simplicity. I just need a place to sleep overnight. The Jane offers a comfortable single bed, with free wireless internet, a free bottle of water, and rates that never seem to vary between 79 and 99 dollars a night. In my at least 10 stays there (all weekend), I have never encountered a problem in the shared bathroom - I've barely seen anyone else and when I do, they are as silent and going about their business as I am. I know they've opened a trendy bar downstairs, but I have yet to encounter the result of that - I must get in for the night too early or something, but I have never heard anything. I wish they had regular elevators, but I don't mind walking and the elevator operators are also de facto customer service - once I bought a good night beer that required an opener and the elevator operator happily accommodated me, and another time my key stopped working, which made me really grumpy, but the elevator operator was able to fix the problem without a visit to the front desk. Really for me, it is a crash pad in the city without the hassle of having to set up arrangements with a friend. And...as a bonus, there is an affordable car lot across the street but I have also found free parking on the street on many occasions. Don't listen to the front desk guy, who is nice but uninformed about the parking situation (as I was when I lived there)....follow the street signs which mostly indicate free parking.

Reviews.Title: “Stay elsewhere- it's still an SRO”
Reviews.Author: dcindc2003
Reviews.Content: The Jane is very cheap- no doubt about that. Location is good, lobby and bar are cute. That's where the positive aspects end. Stayed in a room with bunk beds and tiny doesn't even begin to describe the space. It was about 4x9 and my friend and I could hardly be in the room at the same time except to sleep. What little room there is happens to be very well designed. Don't ask me how they got the bunk beds in there. There are shared bathrooms, which is fine if you don't mind that kind of thing. However, there are still semi-homeless people living there and the conversion from a single occupancy hotel (SRO) is still underway. For the price, there really are other options. Got a room for $99 at the Ace Hotel (nice beds, private bath and 6x the size) after one night at this place.

Reviews.Title: “My first trip to NY”
Reviews.Author: stansorphanage
Reviews.Content: I stayed at The Jane and I had a wonderful time. My girlfriend and I were impressed by the clean and hospitable atmosphere. The posh bar downstairs made it a little embarassing as on the way in as we were often identified as too casual to make it in without a room key, but it was well worth it. I don't recommend a single room for two, as the bed is smaller than a hospital cot. Besides this if you aren't spending much time in your room the size of the area isn't bad. We had a really great stay.

Reviews.Title: “It's all about the staff”
Reviews.Author: HudsonValley558
Reviews.Content: Besides the fact that hotel is still being renovated and is basically a hyped-up dump, the staff is made up of actor wanna-bees that feel they're doing you a favor by granting you permission to spend your money at their hotel. Upon checking out, one female staffer is standing at the front desk complaining because a few "guests" or should I say victims, wanted a late check out. She is telling her fellow staffers that she's going to throw them out if they don't get out by 12:00PM. The bar/lounge is apparently very popular. It must be why the bar manager thinks Barack Obama reports to him. Dude, you run a bar, get over it. In another six months, the hipsters will gone and going to some other scene-of-the-moment locale. People, let's put the hospitality back into the hospitality industry.

Reviews.Title: “Great Value at the Jane”
Reviews.Author: Yantabulla
Reviews.Content: I stayed at The Jane in July 2009 for about 4 nights. The hotel is in a great location in New York. Down a fairly quiet cobblestone street alongside the Hudson. I had an excellent view of the Statue of Liberty from the bathroom. The rooms are very small but they have all the essentials. Great for solo travellers. At the time of my visit there were still a lot of renovation activities going on however that did not detract from my stay. Great value in New York. Excellent reception staff particularly when they got to know you. Don't miss the meatpacking district & the Highline. Negatives - The gouging on my credit card to cover incidentals which was refunded but excessive just the same.

Reviews.Title: “Atmospheric, but smelly and noisy, great bar”
Reviews.Author: Parrot69
Reviews.Content: The dark wood panelling, ghostly lighting, red carpets give this place an incredible atmosphere that makes it worth checking out. I felt like being in the Overlook hotel out of the Shining, so oppressive is the mood. In the bar, the pretty actress about to star in a horror movie sitting next to me admitted she thought it was haunted, and the bar staff heartily agreed there were plenty of spooky tales. Needless to say, it is all fake: even the old wooden panelling was, or so one staff member told me, bought new when the hotel was done up. Nevertheless, the illusion is very real, and the owners have done a sterling job in creating the Jane. That said, it is inconceivable why a recently renovated hotel should smell so bad. The room I slept in the first evening smelled like an aircraft cabin on a long haul flight: of stale, recycled farts and the dried up sweat of three hundred people. I could barely sleep as I kept gagging.The courteous staff changed me into a different room the next day without grumbling, but I shuddder to think what would have happened in high season with the hotel full. While noisy neighbours kept me awake at night, I can accept that as part of the price of staying in a budget hostel, but even a budget hotel should at least be clean. Whatever I saved by staying at the Jane I spent in the bar, which is expensive, but a truly singular place. No wonder it is one of New York's hottest night spots. As the place was being renovated there were no queues at the time. The Jane is worth checking out if you like something quirky, but beware of the smell. Next time, I will rent an apartment, which is about the same price. I'll be back for the bar, though.

Reviews.Title: “Cheap hostel type hotel.”
Reviews.Author: eastcoastballer
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Jane due to its cheap price and its location (which are its positives). However, the negatives far outweigh the positives. For example, the rooms are very, very small. There is barely enough space for one person to change. There is simply not enough space for two people to change....one will have to leave the room for the other to change. The hotel also smells....there is a nasty odor that permeated the halls and rooms. There are local residents that stay in the hotel, and yes, they are strange. The worst part of the hotel is the shower. During our stay, the shower stalls in both bathrooms on the floor were flooded (the drains did not drain the water). You can only imagine how gross this would be to step into and shower. There are much better values for hotels in NYC and even the majority of hostels are much cleaner than this place. Also, the elevator is a lift that was never working, so the stairs were the only option. Do yourself a favor and stay away from this place.

Reviews.Title: “Smelly experience”
Reviews.Author: potterce
Reviews.Content: Hi, I went to the Jane in December. The rooms are small, if you get a bunkbed cabin! You can't get dressed together cause there is no room! The beds are really hard, you can feel the wiress through the matrass. The residents that live there smell really bad and are not friendly. The staff at Cafe Gitane are rude, they keep asking if your done eating when clearly you are not!. And when you give them a tip, they come back for more money.. In short, if you have MORE money, don't go to the Jane! Regards, Caroline

Reviews.Title: “The Jane Hotel in New York”
Reviews.Author: Dutchie27
Reviews.Content: As we were desperately looking for a low budget hotel in New York for September 2009, a New York friend told us about The Jane. It sounded too good to be true; a fair price hotel in the West Village, recently opened and nice looking but small rooms. We were able to book a â€˜cabinâ€™ for two persons for 2 weeks. Arriving at the hotel and seeing our home / cabin for the next two weeks we had the attitude of the positive, still. Okay, it was a very small room with a view on a blind wall and that airco outside was making a lot of noise, but, hey we were in New York. The first night we were completely wasted from the flight from Amsterdam to New York and slept quite early. We woke up in the middle of the night because of the noise coming out of the bar of the hotel downstairs: music, base drums and people in the hallways making a lot of noise. A private party, said the man in the lobby. It was fashion week in New York and it had just begun. â€œAre there parties every night?â€�, we asked the next day. â€œWell, not every night,â€� was the answer, but we could be moved to a room with less noise coming in, on the other side of the hallway. So we did. A room with a view this time and no noisy airco outside. From then on things could only be better. Did it make any difference changing the rooms? Well maybe a little bit but even trying to sleep with earplugs in, didnâ€™t stop the heavy base drums coming through. A few bad nights later we asked to be moved to a higher floor, further away from the noise. We ended up on the 5th floor. The fashion week was about to come to an end, so that must have meant quiet nights and a good sleep finally. Our new neighbour on the 5th floor thought different about this. As soon as he arrived in his cabin (at 5.30 pm) he put his music on and this would continue until 11.30 pm. We tried to talk with him and asked him to put his music down and especially to lower the noise of his base drums. In this way we could watch television and actually hear what was said. But he never even opened his door to talk with us. And what was going on on this 5th floor? We never figured it out. It seemed to us that most of the residents of this floor were residents in the true sense of the word; we thought they were living there permanently. A strange bunch they were, too. What was this man doing in the hallway every time I went to the bathroom, even at 3 oâ€™clock in the morning? He sometimes looked to be in a catatonic freeze and stood there for hours on end. Who was this fat guy making a mess of the bathroom and never saying a word even as he was spoken to? Who lived down our hallway in a cabin full of plastic bags? And where stayed the guy who was always smoking a joint? Coming from Amsterdam we sure do know the smell of it. True, the people who are working in The Jane are very nice and sympathetic. The rooms, bathrooms and linen are cleaned regularly. We made the best of our stay in The Jane. New York is fantastic and we had a wonderful time there. But no way weâ€™ll ever return to The Jane.

Reviews.Title: “Recommended, good location, small rooms”
Reviews.Author: spletzi
Reviews.Content: Rooms are very small (the single-bed room I had was less than 2,50m x 2,00m), but well equiped enabling you deposit (as I did) two large luggage items, several coats and 4 pairs of shoes although no armoire is in place. Room as well as shared bathroom clean. One small note: better make sure everytime that your room is properly closed as I found my room as well as others slightly open (it is not anything tricky, but I found myself disabling actively several times disabling the closing device). For any reason, the heater was on high volume and as I could not find out how to lower the volume, I had the window half-open 24/7. There is also a nice gift from the hotel: a very nice bottle of water. The water was really bad (chlorine taste). Don't try to take this bottle with you! As you can read in the hotel info, the very nice bottle can be purchased for 30 USD. In most cases, mobile phone connection (I had a room to the inner court) was not possible. Room has a flat-screen TV (30 programmes) and an ipod docking station. Staff very nice and the number of guys being at the receoption even at late night is more than you would expect. Similarly, the old-style design seems to be rather upscale. Staff was rather surprised that I gave them a tip (in a modest way). The cafÃ© next-door is quite nice, but - as the area around - rather pricey. The money you save (I paid approx 110 USD incl. tax per night) is nevertheless being spent on the rather pricey delis and cafÃ©s around if you want to have your breakfast in another location. Those are nevertheless in most cases Zagat- and Time-Out-recommended. Final word to the location: 150 metres to the river (between a busy street), 200 metres south of Meatpacking District and the nice Highline Park, it is a 10min walk to the subway. I realised that some taxi drivers have problems finding the street and finally the hotel itself (even the ones just standing 100 metres away...; The Jane is the last building on the street). Finally, it is not inside West Village, but on the Western edge of it. Means: you also need an at least 5 min walk to the cafÃ© mentioned above. Recommended. Would probably choose it again.

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel for solo travellers”
Reviews.Author: A380fan
Reviews.Content: Great interior decoration. Staff always friendly and accomodating. Rooms were small, but had free wifi, TV - plenty of storage space. The lift was such that it was generally far faster to take the stairs. One negative was the noise from the road and draughty windows. Over enthusiastic heating and freezing outside conditions made for a variable room temperature. Never had to wait for a shower (great water pressure). They now give free flipflops and a dressing gown. Will stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “All in all, a very good hotel”
Reviews.Author: softwave
Reviews.Content: All in all, this is a very good hotel. Probably one of the best in its kind. It has great value for money, is full of charm, and has a great, polite, smiling staff. We stayed in a captain's cabin which was large well enough (situated on the corner), but unfortunately, we had a lot of noise from the outside traffic.

Reviews.Title: “I am so impressed...”
Reviews.Author: edmorse
Reviews.Content: I have stayed at the Waldorf, the W, the Grand Hyatt and many other top hotels in NYC. Rarely have I ever spent enough time in the room, worth paying the incredibly high room rates these hotels. When I am able to travel at low volume times and find rock bottom prices at these hotels, my wife is very happy. This last trip, however, my wife was not along and the hotel occupancy in NYC was at it's highest (NCY Marathon week). Two things were most important to me on this trip. Convenience and value. Unfortunately, during marathon week in NYC, these two attributes together are rare when looking for hotels. In fact, I thought it was not possible to find such a hotel, until I found "The Jane." If you are claustrophobic, unwilling to share a bathroom (where showers and toilets are still very private), carry too much luggage, or expect nothing but luxary and plenty of space in a NYC hotel room, then this hotel will not suite your needs. If you are looking for a clean, comfortable, conveniently located hotel in NYC, can handle limited private space (only 50sqft), and don't want to break the bank, then this hotel is for you. The staff is very friendly and helpful. The management is incredible. They are very empathitic to their guest and want to make your stay a great one. Management wants to earn your business and wants you to come back again. They will be opening some rooms that are a little larger and include a bathroom. My wife will be coming next time! Short walk to the subway and a short walk to Pier 59, where the Chelsea Brewery served as my living space. So many good restaurants in the area. My favorite was the small fish and chips restaurant "A Salt and Battery" on Greenwiche. Free High Speed internet was also a big plus. A+++++ in my book!

Reviews.Title: “Nice stay at the Jane.”
Reviews.Author: jagg123
Reviews.Content: I went on my aniversary last novembet 15th. i checked in the jane cause I was staying for 8 nights and the other hotels are very expensive. I read a lot of bad things of the jane, but really it is a great place to sleep, is really clean, the share bathrooms are very clean, the staff is really freindly. The room are really really small, but if you are looking for a place to sleep, it is a great place to stay. My wife and I were looking to get a place to sleep so The Jane it is a great one. Plus is about 10 min. walking to the 8 Ave and 14th St subway station. The neighborhood is pretty safe, between the meetpacking district and Greenwich Village, Chelsea is really near and you can get everywhere by subway.

Reviews.Title: “Great for solo travellers”
Reviews.Author: duncantoms
Reviews.Content: The rooms are just like in the pics on their own site - cabins styled like the early part of the last century. There's a shelf and clothes rail above the bed, draws and luggage space underneath. Views come with the noise of the west side highway, at the back is quieter. My room overlooked a courtyard with trees. AC above the window, and a wall fan. The bathrooms are at the end of each hall, with lockable units for each shower and toilet. I never waited for either. Very nice tiling and rainfall showers. Nice touches: wood panelled rooms, with soft panels around the bed, free replaceable bottled water, old school decor details. The cafe and ballroom closed after the recent licensing controversies. A new cafe is coming soon, looking like a Parisian cafe - may be open by now. About 5% of the rooms on my floor had long term residents in their unrestored rooms. Rooms were a little smelly from the cleaning products used. The beds are right next to the doors, so you hear corridor sounds. Location is excellent - west village, just south of meatpacking, subway a few blocks north at 14th st. Great for $99 in NYC, and a very stylish hotel, in a retro/quirky way.

Reviews.Title: “Great location, really funky, cheapest and best value in NYC, I'd say."”
Reviews.Author: LondonTable_for_One
Reviews.Content: I was gutted I had to leave my little nest in The Jane. I WAS prepared for the size of the single cabin room but not prepared for the dinky space saving touches that came with it...I had a huge suitcase and did endless shopping and it never felt cluttered. They get some things really right...bathrobe with pockets for traipsing to the shower, refilled water bottle every day, iPod dock and radio, DVD player and telly, free (working and fast) wifi. And that was stuff I reckon you shouldn't expect for the price so to get it is a real bonus. I am a big boutique hotel fan and love my luxuries - so I came prepared (bring flip flops for the shower!) My biggest worry was the lack of en suite and honestly, I didn't mind a bit in reality. If you're REALLY squeamish then maybe think twice, but I'm quite a princess and there were NO stinks, kinks or sticking plasters in the showers. In 5 days! Again, for the price and for the 'cool factor' I got over myself pretty quickly! My room wasn't noisy, there were no smelly corridors or weirdos that went bump in the night (but I was prepared to tolerate them all if they happened). The bar downstairs is cool and the bar staff mostly really chatty to my lone female traveller self. I peeked into the ballroom (due to open in a few weeks apparently) and was BLOWN AWAY by it's funky, eclectic, dishevelled in a good way decor. it will be a GREAT asset and there's already a cool little cafe on site. Perfect location too - less than 10 minutes to the subway and RIGHT there in Meatpacking/Greenwich/East Village. Honestly, RIGHT there. Amazing. Sure, you could pay double and get an en suite somewhere a bit dull and dreary without an ounce of real cool. You could pay triple and do the real boutique thing and not have to worry about wearing pajamas at night to go to the bathroom. Or you could stay at The Jane, pack an open mind and some flip flops and love every minute of it.

Reviews.Title: “Interesting place”
Reviews.Author: aott02
Reviews.Content: My in-flight magazine had a review of this hotel that made it sound like the hot spot of NYC. It is in a good area, with lots of restaurant options and small shops, and the subway is about 4 blocks away. The rooms are interesting. It is all about conserving energy, which I like, and it was comfortable, but the single bed is quite small and stiff. We did not get our own bathroom, I don't know if that is an option, but the shared bathrooms were clean and rarely busy. My main problem was the smell in the hall way and the noise in the middle of the night. There was a terrible smell all throughout the hallway, it made me gag each and every time I forgot to hold my breath while walking to or out of my room. I never habituated to the smell. However, when I entered my room I couldn't smell it anymore, so it was ok. The noise though, it wasn't constant, but the walls are paper thin and you can hear everything from all of the other rooms. I believe this place is very popular with young men, and on our first night at 4 AM, one of these men decided to kick our door and start screaming. He then said, "oh S***, there is someone in this room, their stuff was all over the bed this afternoon". I then wondered how he knew my stuff was all over the bed, the only way would be for him to have a key and access to my room while I was out. This was not comfortable at all, but thankfully, I didn't leave anything of value in my room, and nothing was missing after all. You will definitely hear the delightful noises from the hallway as these young people arrive at all times of the night drunk and excited. Overall, the hotel is cute, the room is comfortable enough (definitely not the ritz), but don't expect this to be a place of quiet rest.

Reviews.Title: “Perfect for my first experience of NYC, great location!”
Reviews.Author: Flora1972
Reviews.Content: Like other reviewers on here I was a bit concerned about the Jane prior to our trip. We initially booked our stay back in June and loved the idea of this place, it's quirkiness and also the fact it was a budget hotel. The location of it was also instrumental in our choice as I really wanted to be in West Village having read about it's 'vibe'. So we booked up and were happy. You don't even need to pay a downpayment when you book so if for any reason you have to cancel your trip you don't get charged. Fast forward a few months and just before we leave I read on here a few horror stories about noise from the newly opened bar, roaches and bedbugs and I have to admit in doubting my decision. So I arrived with a can of RAID in my suitcase prepared for all eventualities... But, I have to say hand on heart, the hotel was excellent. Not a bug or roach in sight. The rooms and bathrooms were spotless and cleaned regularly. Rooms cleaned and bed linen changed/turned down daily whilst there. The staff were friendly and accommodating, from the doormen to the lift operator. Everyone was really helpful. And we heard no noise at all (though I suppose we were on the fifth floor). Considering how old the building is, and how small the rooms are, they are very well insulated as you cannot hear much going on once inside your own room. There was even work going on above us and on our floor (they are still refurbishing parts of the hotel) and we never heard a thing. We were put in 2 adjoining rooms on the 5th floor. The tiny cabin like rooms are cleverly designed like ships cabins with a full mirror on one wall so you don't feel too claustraphobic as it creates the feeling of it being bigger. Your suitcase goes under the bed. There is a digital safe in the drawer under the bed also (2 large drawers in all). There are railings on each wall to hang stuff up. There is an iPod dock/alarm clock, a widescreen TV, air con and a wall fan, a robe, x3 towels and a complimentary bottle of water included in the price also. The rooms are powered by an electrical 'key' which you plug in when you enter the room. Bear in mind that you take it out when youleave so anything you leave charging (ie phone) won't be charged as the electricity is only on when this thing is plugged in. Its a good idea to conserve power. Very green! We were early-ish risers due to wanting to explore in our 5 day trip so we got up about 7.30 each day. The bathrooms are situated at either ends of each floor and had two showers (with doors you lock) and two toilets in both. The showers were wonderful, water always hot and shower gel, shampoo and conditioners are also included in their wall dispensers inside the shower. By the bathroom sinks there are hairdryers. I can honestly say in our whole time there we never had to queue to have a shower or if one was occupied you just wandered to the other side to use that one instead. Our floor had quite a few residents (you can tell from their doors as they have key locks instead of the electrical system the hotel uses) but all of them we met were pleasant and friendly, esp one little guy that I kept meeting in the bathrooms while he brushed his teeth. He was very nice but I never found out his name (5th floor opp room 519). Admittedly there is a kind of musty smell in some corridors mostly because some of the residents may smoke in their rooms but on the whole it wasn't unpleasant and there are air fresheners on the walls too. Our room windows faced inward so you only overlook another room's window opposite but there are slatted blinds provided for your privacy at night.
